instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2915: What is 820-2915? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.LP8550: What is LP8550? This is an LED driver responsible for creating the backlight on the LCD screen of Macbooks from 2011 through 2015.
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.BKL_EN: What is BKL_EN? BKL_EN enables backlight. Anytime you see a signal ending with “_EN” , that means this signal being present/high enables what it is referring to. This signal says “BKL” before “_EN”. “BKL” sounds short for “BACKLIGHT”, so it is safe to assume this signal enables backlight when present. .
definitions.LCD_BKLT_EN: What is LCD_BKLT_EN? This is an enable signal. Anytime you see “_EN”, it means when the voltage is high(3.3 volts), whatever it is going to is being turned on or enabled. Here, “LCD_BKLT” which stands for “LCD screen backlight” is being enabled. This signal usually goes to an LED driver used for creating a power rail for the LCD screen backlight, to tell it to turn on & create this rail. .
definitions.BKL_PWM: What is BKL_PWM? BKL_PWM sets the brightness of the screen. The system will send a PWM signal to BKL_PWM pin to set brightness. If this is low, backlight voltage will boost higher than PPBUS_G3H input, but not enough to make the screen light properly..
definitions.LCDBKLT_EN_DIV: What is LCDBKLT_EN_DIV? LCDBKLT_EN_DIV must be low in order for the P channel MOSFET to have a lower voltage on the gate than is present on the source to allow backlight voltage to flow through the backlight circuit. .
definitions.BLK_EN: What is BLK_EN? This is a typo of BKL_EN When you see BLK_EN, assume they meant to type BKL_EN.
definitions.Q9706: What is Q9706? Q9706 takes PPBUS_G3H's vltage and sends it through to the backlight circuit. If Q9706 is not allowing PPBUS_G3H through, you will get no voltage on the backlight circuit. Q9706 is a P channel MOSFET, meaning power will flow through it when the voltage on the gate is lower than on the source. Look at pin 3. R9788 takes the 12.6v that is on the source and places it right on pin 3. This will set Q9706 to "off", and not allow it to pass power, as the voltage on the source and the gate are identical..
definitions.D9701: What is D9701? diode in the backlight circuit sitting between the BKL_SW pin of the LED driver and backlight output. Very common for via between this and BKL_FB for feedback to blow, causing no boost. Measure continuity between pin 2 of this diode and feedback pin of LED driver if backlight output is PPBUS_G3H with no boost.
definitions.SMC_LID_R: What is SMC_LID_R? SMC_LID_R is the signal coming from the hall sensor that detects whether the laptop screen is closed or open. This must be high in order for SMC_LID to be high. SMC_LID has to be high for the machine to not fall asleep and for it to have a backlight..
definitions.SMC_LID: What is SMC_LID? SMC_LID tells the machine the system is open when it is 3.3v to 3.4v, and closed when it is low such as 0v-0.6v. When this signal is low, the machine may go to sleep or have no backlight. .
definitions.LCD_PWR_EN: What is LCD_PWR_EN? LCD_PWR_EN is a signal that tells the chip that supplies power to the LCD screen to turn on..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 1/4 fan spin
threads.message:
Hi I received a board and it had 1/4 fan spin
Replaced <CAPACITOR>C7721</CAPACITOR> it was Still shorted then replaced  <CHIP>U7720</CHIP> and got the board working
Chime, booting, activity on screen but no backlight. After using dosdude gmux I still had no backlight replaced <CHIP>LP8550</CHIP> and fuse
:( now the board is dead again I removed <CHIP>LP8550</CHIP> and I have the
Same short on L7720 and <CHIP>U7720</CHIP>
I didn’t apply a lot of heat and was in and out quickly. What would give me the same short again? I’ve tested around <CHIP>U7880</CHIP> and it’s not shorted also GPU isn’t in direct short. P.S. Board was running for most of the day and at J5650 pin 1 <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> (fan connector) I have 5v but no fan spin :/ I also replace <TRANSISTOR>Q5502</TRANSISTOR>, <TRANSISTOR>Q5501</TRANSISTOR> because they were missing

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 1/4 fan spin
threads.message:
"activity on screen but no backlight. After using dosdude gmux"
Why did you touch GMUX, if had image???

What is the actual state of the board?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 1/4 fan spin
threads.message:
Well 
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>  is 12.53v 
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL> =3.3v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>=5v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL>=3.3v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>=5v 
<SIGNAL>PPDDR_S3_REG_R</SIGNAL>


PCH is Warm CPU is warm

I just flash Gmux in everyone of these Even if its working. just in case.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 1/4 fan spin
threads.message:
Do you get L7220 voltage now?
Board stays on?
Exact VCORE voltage after 10s?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 1/4 fan spin
threads.message:
L7220 =5v
<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_CPU_PH1</SIGNAL>/PH2/PH3= 0v
<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_AXG_L</SIGNAL>=0v

I had a issue on L7720 and that’s still .0v in diode mode to ground

what can kill this IC for a second time ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 1/4 fan spin
threads.message:
My mistake, I wanted to ask about L7720, not L7220.

Can you post exact ohm value on L7720?
Lift it one side and see where the short remains.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 1/4 fan spin
threads.message:
With removed L7720 and <CHIP>U7720</CHIP>
Pin 2 =260 ohms
Pin 1 =OL

I also removed Y5010
And put it aside

before removal of <CHIP>U7720</CHIP> it was 0.v to ground On pin 1 with L7720 removed. 
after removing <CHIP>U7720</CHIP> pin 1 shows OL

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 1/4 fan spin
threads.message:
260 ohm is far away of a short.
I didn't say to remove <CHIP>U7720</CHIP>; resolder it and check again ohm value at L7720 pin 1.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 1/4 fan spin
threads.message:
With <CHIP>U7720</CHIP>, L7720  soldered t’s 22ohms
[COLOR=rgb(44, 130, 201)]260ohms is with both unsolder [/COLOR]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 1/4 fan spin
threads.message:
Then replace <CHIP>U7720</CHIP> and post its new voltages.
Be sure both <RESISTOR>R7720</RESISTOR>/21 are good.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 1/4 fan spin
threads.message: Ok. I recheck <RESISTOR>R7720</RESISTOR>/21 one question can I power on this board wIthout <CHIP>U7720</CHIP> and L7720? I wanna make sure there’s no spikes on <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> that might kill it again

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 1/4 fan spin
threads.message:
Yes, you can.
But <CHIP>U7720</CHIP> should be the last you afraid of <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> spikes.
SMC and PCH are directly connected there, and much more sensitive...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 1/4 fan spin
threads.message: Ok fan spinning ,Chime. Steady 1.8v now on to backlight issue. One question is there a downlink for MRI (resource inspector)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 1/4 fan spin
threads.message:
So board works now, but no backlight?
Do you have image?

Try using Google for MRI...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 1/4 fan spin
threads.message:
Yes I have image no backlight. I have all the enable signals. The resistors on the voltage divider are good and capacitor isn’t shorted. The voyage is 11.53v at gate of mosfet. I believe the mosfet isn’t sending it to ground. But I dont have the part# on my phone it’s on the notepad at home. I’ll get you all the specifics Part# when I get back home. 
I did google mri but I’m confused as to which one is the right link. I found these which is one you’d consider downloading? Or if you have the site and you can point me in the righT direction That would be greatly appreciated

threads.message: Post <SIGNAL>BKL_EN</SIGNAL>/PWM, <SIGNAL>LCD_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>BKLT_PLT_RST_L</SIGNAL> levels; with LCD connected.

threads.message:
<SIGNAL>BLK_EN</SIGNAL> =3.1v
<SIGNAL>BLK_PLT_RST_L</SIGNAL>=3.3v
<SIGNAL>LCD_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL>=3.3v
<SIGNAL>LCDBKLT_EN_DIV</SIGNAL>=4V
<SIGNAL>BKL_PWM</SIGNAL>=2.5v resistor is 33ohm
I’m thinking <TRANSISTOR>Q9706</TRANSISTOR> is bad :/

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 1/4 fan spin
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>LCDBKLT_EN_DIV</SIGNAL>=4V"
You should have (at least) <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> voltage at L9701.
If not, <TRANSISTOR>Q9706</TRANSISTOR> is bad.
Be sure no short to grround at <DIODE>D9701</DIODE> pins; with LCD connected, of course.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 1/4 fan spin
threads.message: Ok so I test for voltage at <CAPACITOR>C9797</CAPACITOR> and got 0v <DIODE>D9701</DIODE> tested good <TRANSISTOR>Q9706</TRANSISTOR> Was internally shorted replaced <TRANSISTOR>Q9706</TRANSISTOR> and have 40v at <CAPACITOR>C9797</CAPACITOR>&<CAPACITOR>C9799</CAPACITOR> but not at <CAPACITOR>C9000</CAPACITOR> or pins 38,39,40 on lvds connector tried running 30awg from <CAPACITOR>C9797</CAPACITOR>&<CAPACITOR>C9799</CAPACITOR> to pond 38,39,40 and got  no backlight. Resistance to ground on these pins reads “OL” Is this gauge Of wire to small? I see there’s some sort of filter but it looks like it’s internal :/

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 1/4 fan spin
threads.message:
Rebuild the trace correctly.
Check connector and video cable for damage.

40V seems to be correct voltage for this 15" model.
Usually voltage goes higher than 50V if LEDs strip don't make contact.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 1/4 fan spin
threads.message: Ok so Once I put wire connected directly to lvds backlight is on. just extremely dim <SIGNAL>BKL_PWM</SIGNAL>=2.5v I would think With that voltage it would have some brightness. But I also might be up against no image on this one :/ As I don’t have a flashing folder. Usb mouse connected and have activity and a chime

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 1/4 fan spin
threads.message:
Image should appear before backlight.
If internal video output is not enabled, no reason to search for backlight.
Do you get voltage at pins 2/3 & 4 of J9000?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 1/4 fan spin
threads.message:
J9000
Pins
2&3 =3.3v
4 = 3.3v
L9010,L9011 have continuity
L9000 has continuity

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 1/4 fan spin
threads.message:
So you have backlight now?
Black, or pure white screen?
Did you try to boot USB macOS?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 1/4 fan spin

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 1/4 fan spin
threads.message: No it won’t boot I have a stage light affect on both screens kind of like when a tv hoes to sleep. I was wondering if maybe this issue is like a lid closed Affect or <SIGNAL>SMC_LID_R</SIGNAL>. Issue? Where the screen thinks it’s closed?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 1/4 fan spin
threads.message:
"J9000
Pins
2&3 =3.3v"
Means <SIGNAL>LCD_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> is present; only possible if <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> signal is correct.

The exact voltage at pins 38-40 of J9000?
Measure with LCD connected, of course.
L9010/11, both good?

Did you check external video?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 1/4 fan spin
threads.message:
well I checked L9010/11 for continuity and they have continuity so I assume they’re good. 
I wont get external video from this unit as dosdudes gmux disables this feature. 
I will measure the 38-40 again. Thank you for your help :)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 1/4 fan spin
threads.message: Also I saw you posted a bios For <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with gpu disabled. Will that survive a nvram ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 1/4 fan spin
threads.message:
BIOS mod does NOT survive PRAM reset.
EFI password must be set, to prevent that.
